raw_text:
Queen recruit singer for new tour
 
 The remaining members of rock band Queen are to go on tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers taking Freddie Mercury's place.
 
 Guitarist Brian May has said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April. May said: "Suddenly the Queen Phoenix is rising again from the ashes and will take precedence over... our lives." Queen have played with many different singers since Mercury's death in 1991 but have reportedly not toured. May performed with Rodgers at a concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster guitar in London in September.
 
 "We were both so amazed at the chemistry that was going on in [Free hit] All Right Now, that suddenly it seems blindingly obvious that there was 'something happening here,'" May wrote on his website. They teamed up again for a concert to mark their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame, and were joined by Taylor. "The show went so incredibly well from our point of view, and we got so many rave reactions from out there, we decided almost then and there that we would look at a tour together," May wrote.
 
 Queen went to number one in 2000 with a version of We Will Rock You sung by boy band 5ive and they have also played with Robbie Williams, Will Young and Bob Geldof. Queen bassist John Deacon has currently retired from the stage. Rodgers was singer with early 1970s rockers Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now, before forming Bad Company, a successful "supergroup" with members of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople. He has also been in The Firm with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and The Law with The Small Faces and The Who drummer Kenny Jones.
llama3.2:1b: Queen will go on tour next year with Paul Rodgers as Freddie Mercury, following Brian May's decision to play with him. May said he expects to be touring with Rodgers from April. He has performed with Rodgers before and was impressed by their chemistry during a concert in September, which led them to consider a tour together.
llama3.2:3b: Queen will tour next year with Paul Rodgers as Freddie Mercury's replacement, joined by guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor from April. This marks the first time Queen has toured since Mercury's death in 1991, after previously performing with various singers.
gemma2:2b: Queen will tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers replacing Freddie Mercury.  Brian May, guitarist for Queen, collaborated with Rodgers at events to celebrate guitar anniversaries, leading to a decision to explore a tour together.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Queen have been playing with Paul Rodgers since 1974, which they refer to as a "Phoenix rise". Queen will be touring with Freddie Mercury's former bandmate Paul Rodgers next year. Queen went on tour with Freddie Mercury in 1980 and are going on tour again with their former friend Paul Rodgers. They performed at a concert in London for the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster guitar. Queen guitarist Brian May has been performing with Rodgers since they met at a concert together, while Roger Taylor has been helping out as a drummer. The group had no tours under their belt until now but are looking to continue their musical journey by playing together again.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Queen will tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers replacing Freddie Mercury, who died in 1991. May performed with Rodgers at a concert marking the Fender Stratocaster guitar's anniversary. Queen has not toured since their death but plans to collaborate with Rodgers for a new tour.
qwen2.5:3b: Queen are to resume touring next year with Paul Rodgers replacing Freddie Mercury, following previous tours featuring other singers since 1991. Guitarist Brian May expects to tour starting April with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor. They performed together at a Fender Stratocaster concert in September, leading to plans for a joint tour. Queen previously toured with Robbie Williams, Will Young, and Bob Geldof, among others. Rodgers was formerly with rock band Free before forming successful supergroup Bad Company.
opencoder:1.5b: The objective is to summarize the given text while preserving the key ideas and details. This means we should focus on the main themes or characters mentioned, their roles, and interactions that happen in the conversation.

Guitarist Brian May has said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April. Queen have played with many different singers since Mercury's death in 1991 but have reportedly not toured. The "something happening here" that was so impressed Brian May and Freddie Mercury is still there, and they're going to be touring together next year. They'll be joined by Roger Taylor from Free and Bad Company, who's been on tour with them for a while now. The show went so incredibly well from our point of view, and we got so many rave reactions from out there, we decided almost then and there that we would look at a tour together. Queen have already done it before with 50 years' worth of touring, but they're going to do it again this time with Rodgers and Taylor.

Queen have already done it before with 50 years' worth of touring, but they're going to do it again this time with Rodgers and Taylor. They've also been in The Firm with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and The Law with King Crimson and Mott the Hoople. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I have this query where the user wants me to summarize a given text into just the key ideas and details. They specified that the output should only be plain text without explanations or any formatting. Let me read through the provided text carefully.

The main event here is that Queen are going on a tour with Paul Rodgers replacing Freddie Mercury. I need to highlight the significance of this change, especially since Freddie Mercury died in 1991, which was when Queen were still together. The original text talks about how the band started with other artists but hasn't toured since then.

Queen's members mention that Brian May is on the road with Rodgers. May expressed surprise they're taking over, something like "the Queen Phoenix rising again." I should note the specific event in London where May performed with him for the Fender Stratocaster anniversary concert. This seems to be a pivotal moment as it shows the band's unity and their musical spirit.

The text also mentions May collaborating with Roger Taylor on a tour event to celebrate induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame, getting rave reactions. It gives examples of Queen's past tours—like 2000 when they sang "We Will Rock You," performed by 5ive; and later with Robbie Williams, The Law, and The Who drummer Kenny Jones.

I need to make sure the summary captures these key points: the replacement of Freddie Mercury with Paul Rodgers, their new tour, May's announcement about the band rising again, the concert in London celebrating Fender, the team-up concert with Taylor, and examples of past tours. I should keep it concise without any extra information.
</think>

Queen are going on a tour next year with former Free singer Paul Rodgers taking Freddie Mercury's place. Brian May has announced his return to the road with him, reflecting the band's unity. They recently performed together at a concert celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster guitar. The show was well-received and led to a tour decision. Queen have also toured with other artists like Robbie Williams, The Law, and Kenny Jones in the past.
tinyllama:1.1b: The remaining members of rock band Queen, guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor, are to embark on a new tour in April alongside former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers. Queen have been playing with various vocalists since Mercury's death in 1991 but this time round they have chosen Rodgers, who has also worked with other popular musicians such as Robbie Williams, Will Young, and Bob Geldof. Queen bassist John Deacon is currently retiring from the stage to focus on family duties, while May himself has retired from performing due to his recent illness. The tour will mark their first since Rodgers' appearance at a concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fenster Strackestar guitar in London.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Queen to tour with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers, guitarist Brian May to take Freddie Mercury's place; band members recruit guitarist Brian May for tours in April following the death of legendary frontman Freddie Mercury.
phi:2.7b: Former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers will join the remaining members of Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor, on tour next year to celebrate Freddie Mercury's 50th anniversary. May has expressed excitement about the tour and hopes it will bring a new energy to their music. They have previously toured with different singers, but not since Mercury's death in 1991. May and Rodgers performed together at a concert to commemorate their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame. They were joined by Taylor for the concert, and are planning a full-fledged tour that they believe will be successful due to the chemistry between them. Queen has achieved international success with their version of We Will Rock You and have played with many different singers throughout their career.
orca-mini:3b: Queen will go on tour with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers next year, replacing their late bandmate Freddie Mercury. Guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor are expected to be part of the tour, which will be led by Queen's lead vocalist. The concert to celebrate their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame featured Rodgers and Taylor.
hermes3:3b: Queen takes Brian May, Roger Taylor as tour members, Paul Rodgers (ex-Free, Bad Company singer) to replace Freddie Mercury.

Guitarist Brian May has said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April. This tour marks Queen's return to the road with a new lead singer, as they have previously toured with various singers since Mercury's death in 1991. The band gained popularity again in 2000 with a version of "We Will Rock You" sung by boy band 5ive.

Guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor will join Rodgers, with the tour starting in April. May and Rodgers first performed together at a Fender Stratocaster anniversary concert and later reunited for the UK Music Hall of Fame, where their chemistry led to the decision to tour. Queen has collaborated with various artists since Mercury's death but has not toured extensively. Bassist John Deacon remains retired. Rodgers, known for his work with Free, Bad Company, The Firm, and The Law, brings extensive rock experience to the collaboration.
stablelm2:1.6b: Queen will be heading on tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers replacing Freddie Mercury as lead vocalist. Brian May expects to join them later, stating that "the Queen Phoenix is rising again." Since Mercury's death, Queen has used various singers but have not toured before. This time around, they will likely perform with Robbie Williams, Will Young, and others. Paul Rodgers was a singer in early rock bands Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now. He later formed successful "supergroups" alongside members of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople. Rodgers has also been involved with artists such as Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Queen, led by Brian May and Roger Taylor, will embark on a new tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers, taking over for the late Freddie Mercury. This marks Queen's first tour since Mercury's death in 1991. The decision to form this lineup was influenced by their strong chemistry during previous collaborations, such as a concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster and their UK Music Hall of Fame induction, where they performed together with Taylor. Rodgers, known for hits like "All Right Now" and successful collaborations with artists like Robbie Williams, has a diverse career including bands like Free, Bad Company, The Firm, and The Law. John Deacon, the band's bassist, is currently retired from live performances.
reference: The remaining members of rock band Queen are to go on tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers taking Freddie Mercury's place.Guitarist Brian May has said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April.May said: "Suddenly the Queen Phoenix is rising again from the ashes and will take precedence over... our lives."Rodgers was singer with early 1970s rockers Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now, before forming Bad Company, a successful "supergroup" with members of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople.Queen have played with many different singers since Mercury's death in 1991 but have reportedly not toured.
